article:
'Herman Andimba Toivo ya Toivo' (born 22 August 1924) is a Namibian politician
who was active in the independence movement. He is a founding member of the
Ovamboland People's Congress (OPC) in 1957, at the beginning of the independence
movement. [http://www.klausdierks.com/Biographies/Biographies_T.htm
Profile at klausdierks.com].

Toivo was born in Omangundu in Oshana Region in the north of Namibia. [http://www.parliament.gov.na/ims/pub/biodatadetail.asp?e=59&i=106
Profile at Namibian Parliament website]. Toivo ya Toivo fought for the
Allied Forces during World War II. Later, because of his political activities in
support of Namibian independence, he was arrested in 1966 by the South African
authorities. On 26 January 1968, he was sentenced by a Pretorian court to 20
years' imprisonment. He was incarcerated at Robben Island, near Cape Town, where
he spent most of his time isolated from his fellow countrymen. Ya Toivo was
released on 1 March 1984. Helao Shityuwete, Never Follow the Wolf, The
Autobiography of a Namibian Freedom Fighter, London 1990, pp. 246â47.

From 1984 to 1991, he was the Secretary General of the South West Africa
People's Organization (SWAPO).

Toivo was a SWAPO member of the Constituent Assembly, which was in place from
November 1989 to March 1990, immediately prior to independence, [http://www.parliament.gov.na/ims/pub/getindivs.asp?e=65&en=Constituent%20As-
sembly%20of%20Namibia%20November%201989%20-%20March%201990 List of members of
the Constituent Assembly], parliament.gov.na. and upon independence in
March 1990 he became a member of the National Assembly. He was
also Minister of Mines and Energy from 1990 until
his appointment as Minister of Labour on 26 March
1999. [http://www.namibian.com.na/Netstories/March99/strategy.html "Two-
prong strategy in latest reshuffle"], The Namibian, 29 March 1999. After
over three years in that position, he was appointed as Minister of Prisons on 27
August 2002, switching posts with Marco Hausiku; Christof Maletsky,
[http://www.namibian.com.na/2002/august/news/027F52F716.html "Nujoma shuffles
the Cabinet pack"], The Namibian, 28 August 2002. he remained Minister of
Prisons until 2006.

He chose not to run for a seat in the National Assembly again at the time of the
2004 election, saying that he had "done enough". Tangeni Amupadhi,
[http://www.namibian.com.na/2004/october/national/046C49FBA1.html "Major shift
in Swapo leadership"], The Namibian, 4 October 2004.

Toivo received the eleventh-most votes—358—in the election to the
Central Committee of SWAPO at the party's August 2002
congress. [http://www.namibian.com.na/2002/august/news/027EBA9751.html "The
ruling party's new Central Committee"], The Namibian, 27 August 2002. At
SWAPO's November 2007 congress, Toivo failed to be elected to the SWAPO
Politburo for the first time in the party's history. This was attributed to
Toivo's purported link to the opposition Rally for Democracy and Progress (RDP),
a party that had been founded as a split from SWAPO shortly before the congress.
Toivo denied being linked to the RDP, but the claim was believed to have
influenced the vote. Christof Maletsky,
[http://www.namibian.com.na/2007/December/national/07D12794AF.html "Swapo big
names dropped"], The Namibian, 3 December 2007.

At the SWAPO Congress on 2 December 2012, Andimba ya Toivo was elected as a
permanent member of the Central Committee.  The Namibian, [http://www.nami-
bian.com.na/index.php?id=28&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=104941&no_cache=1], The
Namibian 3 December 2012.

He lives with his wife and two daughters.
categories: Members of the National Assembly of Namibia
Members of the South West Africa People's Organization
Namibian people of World War II
